acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its 96-hour EbC50 = 0.24 mg/L for algae (chlorella) (IUCLID, 2000), the substance was classified into Category 1.

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Both of two LD50 values documented: 1200 mg/kg for rats (OECD TG 402) (IUCLID (2000)) and 1990 mg/kg for rabbits (HSDB (2005)), fall under Category 4.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Of four rat LD50 values documented: 48 mg/kg, 91 mg/kg (male), 81 mg/kg (female), and 59 mg/kg (ATSDR (1995)), three values fall under Category 3. Thus, the substance was classified into Category 3.

carcinogenicity.rationale: The mixture of isomers was rated as Group 2B by the IARC (HSDB (2004)) and Classification D by the EPA (IRIS (2005)). However, due to lack of data on 1,3-dinitrobenzene, classification is not possible.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its classification for acute toxicity is Category 1, and it is not rapidly degradable (BIOWIN), the substance was classified into Category 1.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available.

explosives.rationale: It contains chemical groups associated with explosive properties, and its oxygen balance is -952, which is lower than -200. Thus, the substance was classified into the "Not classified" category.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Classification is not possible due to lack of in vivo test results as well as strong positive results in in vitro mutagenicity tests using several indices. Regarding in vitro mutagenicity tests, choromosomal aberration tests using V 79 cells gave positive results (IUCLID (2000)) and Ames tests also yielded positive results (NTP DB (accessed in September 2008)).

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure

oxidizing_solids.rationale: The molecule contains oxygen, which is bonded to elements other than carbon or hydrogen. Due to lack of data on its oxidizing properties, the substance was classified into the "Classification not possible" category.

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: It is categorized into the UNRTDG's Class 6 (UN No. 3443).

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: In oral administration tests using female and male rats, effects of administration on fertility, such as loss of coitus ability, diminished sperm production, and decreased cauda epididymal sperm reserves, were noted (BUA Report (1992), HSDB (2005), etc.). Based on these results, the substance was classified into Category 2.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid (melting point <= 140degC) substances are not available.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: It is categorized into the UNRTDG's Class 6 (UN No. 3443).

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Rabbit tests found that the substance is mildly irritating (ATSDR (1995)). Based on this result, it was classified into Category 2. In other rabbit tests (OECD TG 405 GLP), the substance was found to be irritating (IUCLID (2000)).

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Rabbit tests (OECD TG 404 GLP) found that the substance is not irritating (IUCLID (2000)). Based on this document, the substance was classified into the "Not classified" category.

skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
skin_sensitizer.rationale: Since guinea pig maximization tests (OECD TG 406 GLP) found that the substance is skin sensitizing (50% positive reaction rate) (IUCLID (2000)), it was classified into Category 1.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (blood system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: In 12-week forced oral administration (5 days per week) tests using rats, splenic hemosiderosis (1.5 mg/kg) accompanied with hemolytic anemia were detected at 0.75-6 mg/kg, which fall under Category 1 guidance doses (ATSDR (1995)). Thus, the substance was classified into Category 1 (blood system). Also, there is a report that in rat oral route administration tests, testicular germinal epithelial cells, which had sloughed off the testicular epithelium, were observed in caput epididymal fluid (HSDB (2005)).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (blood system, nervous system)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: In forced oral administration tests using rats, presence of methemoglobin (28%) and cyanosis were noted at 25 mg/kg, which falls under Category 1 guidance doses (ATSDR (1995)), and increased erythropoietic activity was detected at 15 mg/kg (ATSDR (1995)). In other forced oral administration tests using rats, ataxia was observed at 48 mg/kg, which falls under Category 1 guidance doses (ATSDR (1995)), and flaccid paralysis was noted at 20 mg/kg (HSDB (2005)). Based on these results, the substance was classified into Category 1 (nervous system and blood system).
